channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Get your foot in the door! UK/EU Remote Jr. Perl Developer
item.description: We know that a lack of commercial experience doesn’t always reflect skill level, know-how, or programming brilliance. You know your stuff. You’re keen to grow and learn. You know that if someone would only just give you a chance, and let you in the door, you could really shine!

item.title: A Job that Fits. 100% remote (within UK) Perl dev. Role
item.description: Our client’s mission is to empower citizens to participate in civic matters by providing the technology, tools, and data they need. From a platform that enables citizens to report roads that need fixing to democratic tools that connect citizens with politicians, this dynamic organization is changing the world for the better, one click at a time.

item.title: Can’t find the right job? Build your own! Remote Perl role in Australia
item.description: If you’re a senior Perl developer — you’ve already got the most important component of what our client is looking for. Other important bits: in an ideal world, you’ll have experience with most or all of Catalyst, REST, Dancer2, Moo, DBlx::Class, MySQL, Postgres, and docker. Want to add extra flair? AngularJS or Vue would take you to the next level.

item.title: Cruise into this Dreamy Career. Perl role in Malta
item.description: Our client is an international company who pride themselves on making online trading a breeze. After twenty-plus years cruising the financial waters, they’re subject matter experts who provide a stable, engaging environment for their crew. Located in glorious Malta, they offer a supportive team that believes in open communication and solving problems together.

item.title: Do you speak two languages? Remote UK Perl role
item.description: More than one million happy customers have used this company’s award-winning product portfolio to make low-cost multi-currency payments across different payment products. This group thrives on supporting their clients with a one-two combination of personalized expert service and advanced payment technology. Sr. devs who are engaged with the industry and eager to try new things will do well here.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Clarity versus brevity
item.description: A very unique style of blogging focus on task analysis. Keep it up great work.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 142
item.description: Luis detailed analysis of Sleep Sort is highly recommended. Thank you Luis.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 142: divide and sleep
item.description: Luca also used Promise of Raku to solve the Sleep Sort task. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 142: Divisor Last Digit and Sleep Sort
item.description: Laurent introduced await of Raku to solve Sleep Sort task.

item.title: PWC142 - Sleep Sort
item.description: Thanks for introducing Promise of Raku. Nice example to learn new tricks in Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: PWC142 - Divisor Last Digit
item.description: Loved the Raku solution with all type constraints. Raku Rocks.

item.title: Sleep On It: The Weekly Challenge #142
item.description: Dave shared bonus solution in Node.js for the task Sleep Sort. Great example to follow. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: At Sleep at Last with Raku
item.description: A very interesting solution to Sleep Sort in Raku. Thanks Arne for sharing the magic.

item.title: Sleeping Divisors
item.description: Adam being the person proposing Sleep Sort task, gone in details with interesting background.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 142: Divisor Last Digit
item.description: Once again, one more one-liner in Perl to the solve the task.

item.title: Meet The Champion - W. Luis Mochan
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 142
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Divisor Last Digit" and "Sleep Sort" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 143
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Calculator" and "Stealthy Number". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: A (not so) simple matter of privacy
item.description: Damin shared one of the issue dicussed in the meeting with Perl Steering Committee with regard to the best way to provide private methods in Corinna.

item.title: JavaScript Supported Web Scraping using Perl and Selenium
item.description: If you want to scrape web contents, this article explains how to scrape web contents using Perl and Selenium.

item.title: My Favorite Warnings: shadow
item.description: Tom discussed another favourite warnings shadow in the on going blog series.

item.title: Sweeter Perl exception classes
item.description: Mark shared different ways to deal with exception in Perl. A very thought provoking.

item.title: Corinna Update 8th Dec 2021
item.description: Some more updates to how Class data and methods are agreed to be declared. And few more.

item.title: Corinna Update 6th Dec 2021
item.description: After considerable discussion, slot has been renamed to field.

item.title: #542 - Perl Advent Calendar
item.description:
Hi there

How you all doing? Are you making the most of festive season?

In the 540th edition of the weekly newsletter, I mentioned Advent Calendar. I did see some activities in the GitHub repository for Perl Advent Calendar. I was hoping to see another exciting edition full of Perl projects. A friend of mine on Facebook mentioned that this year Perl Advent Calendar is looking a bit sparse. At the time of writing this editorial, I only saw one post i.e. Day 1 of Year 2021. Being one of many contributors in the past, I am sad to see the current state. I have absolutely no idea what happened this year. I know I have too many things already on my plate but I would like to help to get Perl Advent Calendar back to its original glory.

Talking about Advent Calendar, I would like to mention about The Weekly Challenge Advent Calendar which has mix of Perl and Raku like in the past. We have been running this since the beginning i.e. 2019. You will find some of the fun tasks from the past one year being discussed by members of Team PWC. I have made slight change to the look and feel this time. I hope you like it too

How about 24 Pull Requests event?

I have not seen it being discussed either on any of the social platforms e.g. Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn. I haven't had chance to take part this year. I couldn't take part last year too, what a shame. I still have 10 days and I have booked few days off from work. So there is a possibility I might take part and even complete the challenge. Please wish me luck.

Last but not the least, Curtis, leading the project Corinna, announced that he had a great meeting with the Perl Steering Council and they are extremely receptive to Corinna going into the core. I can't wait for Corinna being part of core Perl. Damian shared the details on one of issues discussed in the same meeting in the blog. You definitely don't want to miss it.

Enjoy the newsletter.
